Before I always avoided computer science topics. I always felt overwhelmed even though I belong to the hard sciences. Didn't bother me, I mean, my career should be totally independent from this. But lately at work, I'm dealing with so much data gathering and excel won't cut out--it's an inefficient nightmare. After that, I just knew I had to do something. I'm so happy to at least consider making myself literate and in this journey, this crash course series has been so enjoyable, my younger self would be so surprised. Kudos to you miss and your whole team. The effect is surely exponential. To be honest, i think that education for computer literacy should be as important and free as reading and writing in the future.

bill Niko no, there ain’t right, I was try gonna to express every language follow the up to down rules, maybe your mistake understanding was from loop. Also loop won’t break up to down rules. Think of this we will get ambiguity if we don’t have up to down rules such as the codes below :  for 1...2 {   var a = 1  var b = 0    If a == 1 {     b += 1   }   If a == 1 {     b -= 1   }   print(b)  }  We will get unpredictable result If we don’t have up to down rules while loop it in this scenario. The loop won’t break the up to down rules.

Love all CC videos thank you. In my opinion I do think the definitions are a bit rushed and it may be difficult for a new coder to watch this video and then explain what a function is. I'd describe a function as a nested block of code that performs some logic and can be called repeatedly at other points. This saves a coder from retyping those rules over and over again and they can simply reference the function they created.

So if you're writing a program in, say, C+, do you have to wait for the program to get to an if/then statement, or will it constantly be checking for all the if/then statements in the program?  For something like a video game it seems like you would need the computer to react nearly instantly to an if/then statement in some cases (if damage > 100, you die), but if the computer has to follow the program one step at a time like a recipe it seems like that might not work as well.

Here is a pseudo-code example in Lua 5.1 for searching directories and subdirectories, while using the recursion principle: function searchDirectories(path, _files)  if (!filesystem.isDirectory(path))   return path;  end   local files = _files or {};   for _, file in pairs(filesystem.getFileList(path)) do   local fPath = path + "/" + file;   if (filesystem.isDirectory(fPath))    searchDirectories(fPath, files);   else    table.insert(files, fPath);   end  end   return files; end

My favorite type of function is recursive function, to understand recursive function we must first talk about my favorite type of function is recursive function, to understand recursive function we must first talk about my favorite type of function is recursive function, at this point you should understand what a recursive function is, it is a function that calls it self usually until a statement is false, the utility in recursion in opposition to a loop is that you can keep track of transformed data more efficiently then a loop, say you write a pathing function to have something at point A find the shortest path to point B you could recursively send yourself in every direction and return the instruction for the shortest path, although more polish would be coded such as estimating the shortest path to begin with and then circumventing obstacles recursion helps keep track of the data better then a loop would.

It's fairly common for me at least to remake an already existing function in a library somewhere either because it provides too little functionality for my purposes or too much. For example I made something which required me to calculate powers of 2 a lot of times per frame (I can't for the life of me remember why), and for some reason the standard library function was incredibly slow, so I just made this function below (javascript) and it drastically increased the performance of whatever I was making. function Pow2(n){     var Result=1;     while(n--) Result += Result;     return Result; }

I am an experienced professional, and I actually do not have a problem with long functions, so long as the level of abstraction is consistent throughout.  What people frequently do is incorrectly associate function length with complexity.  Spaghetti code is caused by a number of factors, which can also bloat the size of the function, but the length of the function in and of its self is not the problem.  In some cases, I prefer a long, flat function to perform certain tasks like initialization of large systems or UIs, validation of long forms, or itemized processing as opposed to componentizing everything and having to jump across the whole codebase to assemble a complete picture of what is happening.  The fixation on function length as a metric is a great example of a principle being applied without context, and in my opinion, is the mark of a naive programmer.

Its hard to write bad code, if you write sparse code. That is, if your function is more than even 50 lines, there is definitely a part or two that can form its own function. And that doesn't mean it is written poorly. The main reason to try and keep a program modular is for the people who will use your code in the future. I understand that programmers can write a proper, useful, but extremely long functions. However, that would make things more difficult for the others who use it. If you can either explain how "nobody ever uses these applications for anything productive ever," give examples of "productive" Python software that doesn't use functions, or give examples of "productive" Java software that doesn't use methods, then you might have a point.  In truth, the issue of using functions and methods is a question of efficiency within a program rather than productivity, as doing such may actually be slower than something else.  In reality, unless a program demands insanely optimized efficiency, then using Functions speeds up development time while reducing errors.  In Software, doing something like this would be inane compared to coding certain parts of an application in a lower level language so as to reduce a bottleneck of lag.  In Application Development, Functions and Methods can speed up development time and reduce errors at downside of a usually unnoticeable amount of lag.  In Scientific Programming, Scientists who specialize in a discipline such as Biology or Psychology as opposed to Computer Science can use a simple high level language like Python for practically anything they would need themselves.

Don't kid yourself, for loops are exactly the same as while loops (with a few exceptions like python). In many programming languages for loops look something like this:  for( statement0; expression; statement1 ) {     DoSomething(); }  It'll execute statement0 once at the start, and for every loop check if the expression is true (if not exit the loop), do the thing in the loop and execute statement1. This is exactly the same as the following:  statement0; while( expression ) {     DoSomething();     statement1; }  The only reason to use one above the other is clarity, but they're not actually different.

A while loop is not the same as for loop. You need to know the number of iterations beforehand in for loops, but you don't need this information in while loops. Here's how to use the while loop:  while(condition) {         some code; }

That's exactly equivalent to the following for loop in C++:  for (;condition;) {     some code; }  The statements which normally appear in the head of a for loop are optional. In fact, even the following is valid and expresses an infinite loop:  for (;;) {     some code; }

for (;condition;) {       some code; }  Basically a for loop is just a while loop with a built-in initializing statement and iteration statement. You don't even have to provide the init or iter, and bam it's a while loop. You don't need to know the number of iterations.  For example: for(;runComplicatedCondition();doSomethingAfterEachLoop()) {       more strange code made by Ply; }  Terder!

You're very close, but you forgot one important difference. Unlike while loops, for loops also keep the variable(s) inside the loop's scope, which both frees up the variable names for reuse later on (so that you don't need to come up with new names for each loop), and makes sure that old loop variables can't be used somewhere else by mistake.   Example:  int i = 0; while (i < 10){     print (i);     i++; } int j = 0; while (j < 10){     // Bug! This is actually an infinite loop since j never increases. With for-loops, this can't happen.     print (i);     i++; }  To make them the same, you would also have to wrap the while loop in curly brackets, like this:  {     statement0;     while( expression ) {         DoSomething();         statement1;     } }

The importance of for loops (and the even more abstract foreach loops) is not that they allow you to do something while loops can't.  They are just a tiny layer of abstraction on top of while loops, and their value is that they let the programmer communicate something about their intentions.  In particular, for loops tend to send the message 'I'm going to make the same update to a bunch of independent things', whereas a while loop sends the message 'I'm going to keep updating the same thing over and over until I'm done with it'.  For loops hint at independent work; work that might be able to be done in parallel if it turns out to be expensive.  While loops tend to indicate that future iterations have some dependency on previous iterations.

Functional programming ideas can be great for the parts of your program that need to 'calculate an answer'.  Many introductory programming assignments will be programs that fall entirely into this category.  However, this only represents a subset of the vast array of problem types that a a developer working on a larger application typically needs to solve.  If the application is interactive in any way, it is going to need state, and a way of updating that state incrementally over time.  Similarly, object oriented programming might be a decent way to organize parts of that state... the parts that look like self contained objects.  But not all data and functions are best organized this way.  Applied indiscriminately to the wrong problems, object oriented designs can introduce huge layers of extra complexity and even cause code to be less modular instead of more.  There are lots of available abstractions in programming, and many of them are orthogonal.  Learning one set of abstractions in no way locks you out of adding other independent abstraction concepts to your tool belt.  Over time experience with mixing and matching different techniques will build your intuition about where each approach works best.  But it is a mistake to think that you need to choose a particular school of thought from among mutually exclusive options.  Few, if any, are actually mutually exclusive, and I have yet to see a case where using one boxes you out of using any other in different parts of the same project.

The counting for loop is not "also largely dropped from modern languages." There may be better alternatives in most modern languages but it's still in there and it's still a useful thing to discuss when talking about iteration without getting into arrays and things.

Mike Meyer I don't see what difference the back end implementation of the for loop makes, in this context, when the usage is still the same. I can't speak for all of those languages but most of them still supply a for(x; x<y; x++) style of loop control, regardless of how it works after compilation this is still extremely useful to know about. This is syntactically different from the example given in the video, but only in the same way that if/else syntaxes vary from what is present here as well.  I guess I'm not sure what your point is at this juncture.
The shown for loop "for i = 1 to 10 (newline) [...] next" could perfectly well be a foreach type loop, if "1 to 10" is syntax sugar for a range.

I'm actually not sure if I agree that a counting-style for loop is obsolete. I suggest you take a look at the Algol do construct or Lisp's  loop macro. The idea there is that loops can combine multiple conditionals, like:  Common Lisp: (loop for i from 1 to 10 by 2 while (f i) do ...)  Algol: for i from 1 by 2 to 10 while f(i)<4 do [content of loop] od  I.e. where the counting for loop, the while loop, and the foreach loop over an iterable are all actually special cases of a bigger more flexible looping construct. The C-like for loop was a significant downgrade imho, since it's just syntax sugar for a while loop with a statement before it and a statement that goes inside it. Foreach loops over an iterator with iterator combinors like enumerate or zip are okay, but I still miss the more flexible looping constructs.

The real reason why the feature has been rare is because of the huge influence of C, and because most imperative languages designed in the 80s and 90s didn't want any loop construct that wasn't present in C. It took C++ thirty years to adopt a foreach loop, and Java itself only adopted it after more than a decade.  Python was an odd one out, and had the foreach loop as the default because it empathizes generators more than any other language.  Most of the other languages that didn't go for a C-like syntax with curlies didn't go back to a more general loop construct because they simply didn't empathize loops at all, and instead encourage using pipelines or higher order functions. Whether they did it in the OO-with-blocks style of Ruby, or in a straight up functional style like the Haskell/ML family.

there is a website called Codecademy. You can learn almost all programming languages

https://www.codecademy.com/ is a good start, as well as https://www.w3schools.com/. Keep in mind, that learning a programming language is much like a spoken language, you'll want to know the syntax (grammar) and operands first and try simple snippets of codes, before you can make a full program your project.

I can confirm codecademy is a great way to learn how to program interactively, though it's fairly restrictive. If you like learning on your own more, I'd still advice starting with codecademy just for the basics, but switch over to khanacedemy. They have challenges too, but they hold your hand less, and you can also just create your own project and start messing around. Two general tips for starting programmers: google is your friend, along with a site that provides documentation (different for every programming language), the most experienced programmers still use/need them. And tip 2: don't take error messages at face value. Often something else is wrong, and often on the line before the one that gave you an error.
